content:
⚠️ Modified the Contribution.
Comment: Author has not responded to issues raised about the validators not testing anywhere near the same scale of inputs as the test cases. For now, I've added a Test/Validator pair (6) to focus on the largest cases, moved Test 5's input of 123456789 to Test 6 to form part of this pair, made Test 5 simple to match Validator 5's scale (9090) and added a Validator 6 (111222333). Also added a write statement to the stub generator.

Solving this for large n is a waste of coder's time, because your validators don't even go above 60000.
I'd suggest removing the 123456789 test case and the line about "Please put some more efficiency to pass more test cases.".

Solving this inefficiently is fine, if people want to win shortest mode they can utilise the trick that you used where the answer is basically 2**(the number of 0's in the binary of n)
Test 5 and Validator 5 should have similar ns. Straight forward solution passes all the validators but fail on Test 5.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice problem

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This clash is very easy and simple, and it's a good clash for COC too

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it was a good idea
Please consider everyone's comments and remove the quotes from the stub generator.

I agree with the others' comments on how to improve the clash. I have only one more comment for now.

Output section - Please change the wording to:
An integer for the number of values which satisfy the crieria

Hi, a couple things:

- The case n=0 appears only in Val. 6 and might throw a lot of people off if this goes approved. I suggest to put it in the tests.

- The wording of the statement:
#Given an integer n , find each x such that:
#...
#Return the number of x's satisfying the criteria.
could be:
#Given an integer n , return the number of x's such that:
I say this because I spent a couple mins outputting the x's instead of the number of them (maybe I don't know how to read...).

- I think you should put somewhere in the statement that some sort of efficiency is required (a naive approach won't pass Test 5).

Fun clash!

I think you must use 'XOR' in place of '^'

If ^ is XOR in a lot of C-like language, in other language ^ can be used for the 'power' operation.

Hello there, Please try in IDE before moving to the solution

Thanks,
Tangent

Thank you sir,
I will update

Thank you,
I will update it

Thank you,
I will update it

It's not an easy thing to guess while solving this in 15 minutes, but that test case and 'efficiency' line in the statement make it seem like you need to find the trick to pass the validators, which you don't.

Much better to keep it simple and let people solve in by brute force if they want, the validators already let them do so anyway.
